canto1.1: Midway upon the journey of our life
canto1.2: I found myself within a forest dark,
canto1.3: For the straightforward pathway had been lost.
canto1.4: Ah me! how hard a thing it is to say
canto1.5: What was this forest savage, rough, and stern,
canto1.6: Which in the very thought renews the fear.
canto1.7: So bitter is it, death is little more;
canto1.8: But of the good to treat, which there I found,
canto1.9: Speak will I of the other things I saw there.
canto1.10: I cannot well repeat how there I entered,
canto1.11: So full was I of slumber at the moment
canto1.12: In which I had abandoned the true way.
canto1.13: But after I had reached a mountain’s foot,
canto1.14: At that point where the valley terminated,
canto1.15: Which had with consternation pierced my heart,
canto1.16: Upward I looked, and I beheld its shoulders,
canto1.17: Vested already with that planet’s rays
canto1.18: Which leadeth others right by every road.
canto1.19: Then was the fear a little quieted
canto1.20: That in my heart’s lake had endured throughout
canto1.21: The night, which I had passed so piteously.
canto1.22: And even as he, who, with distressful breath,
canto1.23: Forth issued from the sea upon the shore,
canto1.24: Turns to the water perilous and gazes;
canto1.25: So did my soul, that still was fleeing onward,
canto1.26: Turn itself back to re-behold the pass
canto1.27: Which never yet a living person left.
canto1.28: After my weary body I had rested,
canto1.29: The way resumed I on the desert slope,
canto1.30: So that the firm foot ever was the lower.
canto1.31: And lo! almost where the ascent began,
canto1.32: A panther light and swift exceedingly,
canto1.33: Which with a spotted skin was covered o’er!
canto1.34: And never moved she from before my face,
canto1.35: Nay, rather did impede so much my way,
canto1.36: That many times I to return had turned.
canto1.37: The time was the beginning of the morning,
canto1.38: And up the sun was mounting with those stars
canto1.39: That with him were, what time the Love Divine
canto1.40: At first in motion set those beauteous things;
canto1.41: So were to me occasion of good hope,
canto1.42: The variegated skin of that wild beast,
canto1.43: The hour of time, and the delicious season;
canto1.44: But not so much, that did not give me fear
canto1.45: A lion’s aspect which appeared to me.
canto1.46: He seemed as if against me he were coming
canto1.47: With head uplifted, and with ravenous hunger,
canto1.48: So that it seemed the air was afraid of him;
canto1.49: And a she-wolf, that with all hungerings
canto1.50: Seemed to be laden in her meagreness,
canto1.51: And many folk has caused to live forlorn!
canto1.52: She brought upon me so much heaviness,
canto1.53: With the affright that from her aspect came,
canto1.54: That I the hope relinquished of the height.
canto1.55: And as he is who willingly acquires,
canto1.56: And the time comes that causes him to lose,
canto1.57: Who weeps in all his thoughts and is despondent,
canto1.58: E’en such made me that beast withouten peace,
canto1.59: Which, coming on against me by degrees
canto1.60: Thrust me back thither where the sun is silent.
canto1.61: While I was rushing downward to the lowland,
canto1.62: Before mine eyes did one present himself,
canto1.63: Who seemed from long-continued silence hoarse.
canto1.64: When I beheld him in the desert vast,
canto1.65: “Have pity on me,” unto him I cried,
canto1.66: “Whiche’er thou art, or shade or real man!”
canto1.67: He answered me: “Not man; man once I was,
canto1.68: And both my parents were of Lombardy,
canto1.69: And Mantuans by country both of them.
canto1.70: ‘Sub Julio’ was I born, though it was late,
canto1.71: And lived at Rome under the good Augustus,
canto1.72: During the time of false and lying gods.
canto1.73: A poet was I, and I sang that just
canto1.74: Son of Anchises, who came forth from Troy,
canto1.75: After that Ilion the superb was burned.
canto1.76: But thou, why goest thou back to such annoyance?
canto1.77: Why climb’st thou not the Mount Delectable,
canto1.78: Which is the source and cause of every joy?”
canto1.79: “Now, art thou that Virgilius and that fountain
canto1.80: Which spreads abroad so wide a river of speech?”
canto1.81: I made response to him with bashful forehead.
canto1.82: “O, of the other poets honour and light,
canto1.83: Avail me the long study and great love
canto1.84: That have impelled me to explore thy volume!
canto1.85: Thou art my master, and my author thou,
canto1.86: Thou art alone the one from whom I took
canto1.87: The beautiful style that has done honour to me.
canto1.88: Behold the beast, for which I have turned back;
canto1.89: Do thou protect me from her, famous Sage,
canto1.90: For she doth make my veins and pulses tremble.”
canto1.91: “Thee it behoves to take another road,”
canto1.92: Responded he, when he beheld me weeping,
canto1.93: “If from this savage place thou wouldst escape;
canto1.94: Because this beast, at which thou criest out,
canto1.95: Suffers not any one to pass her way,
canto1.96: But so doth harass him, that she destroys him;
canto1.97: And has a nature so malign and ruthless,
canto1.98: That never doth she glut her greedy will,
canto1.99: And after food is hungrier than before.
canto1.100: Many the animals with whom she weds,
canto1.101: And more they shall be still, until the Greyhound
canto1.102: Comes, who shall make her perish in her pain.
canto1.103: He shall not feed on either earth or pelf,
canto1.104: But upon wisdom, and on love and virtue;
canto1.105: ’Twixt Feltro and Feltro shall his nation be;
canto1.106: Of that low Italy shall he be the saviour,
canto1.107: On whose account the maid Camilla died,
canto1.108: Euryalus, Turnus, Nisus, of their wounds;
canto1.109: Through every city shall he hunt her down,
canto1.110: Until he shall have driven her back to Hell,
canto1.111: There from whence envy first did let her loose.
canto1.112: Therefore I think and judge it for thy best
canto1.113: Thou follow me, and I will be thy guide,
canto1.114: And lead thee hence through the eternal place,
canto1.115: Where thou shalt hear the desperate lamentations,
canto1.116: Shalt see the ancient spirits disconsolate,
canto1.117: Who cry out each one for the second death;
canto1.118: And thou shalt see those who contented are
canto1.119: Within the fire, because they hope to come,
canto1.120: Whene’er it may be, to the blessed people;
canto1.121: To whom, then, if thou wishest to ascend,
canto1.122: A soul shall be for that than I more worthy;
canto1.123: With her at my departure I will leave thee;
canto1.124: Because that Emperor, who reigns above,
canto1.125: In that I was rebellious to his law,
canto1.126: Wills that through me none come into his city.
canto1.127: He governs everywhere, and there he reigns;
canto1.128: There is his city and his lofty throne;
canto1.129: O happy he whom thereto he elects!”
canto1.130: And I to him: “Poet, I thee entreat,
canto1.131: By that same God whom thou didst never know,
canto1.132: So that I may escape this woe and worse,
canto1.133: Thou wouldst conduct me there where thou hast said,
canto1.134: That I may see the portal of Saint Peter,
canto1.135: And those thou makest so disconsolate.”
canto1.136: Then he moved on, and I behind him followed.
